properties.desc:
"The days that followed brought hunger, death, and panic to our people. We could neither eat nor sleep. At first, in a new home on Zielna Street, we knew real comfort." (15)

"Our house at 31 Zielna Street was next to the telephone building, which was a target for the German guns throughout the siege. . . . [O][ne of the bombs exploded in the front room of our apartment, and we were forced to return to the crowded home of our relatives." (15–16)

"The Nazis are beginning to intensify their acts of terrorism against the native population, especially the Jews. Last week they set fire to the great synagogue, the pride of the Lodz community. They forbade the Jews to remove the sacred books, and the 'shames' or beadle who wanted to save the holy relics was locked up inside the temple and died in the flames." (19)
"This is only the third day of our internment in the Pawiak prison, but I can hardly believe that we have not been here much longer, for so many things have happened during this short time."(162)
"I felt choked by tears when we drove down Leszno Street. How much Jewish blood has been shed here. . . . We were silent, and our Gentile companions sympathized with us." (216)

"We are now staying in two small rooms at 41 Sienna St., where a cousin of ours also lives. Because this apartment house belongs to the officials of a German bank, the Germans have allocated sufficient fuel for its maintenance. Thus we are protected from the terrible cold." (25, 5 January 1940)

"The youth circle of our house at 41 Sienna Street helps Dr. Janusz Korczak's Children's Home. Every day two of our members are appointed to make collections, and everyone, even those who themselves need help, willingly give to Dr. Korczak's little wards." (54–55, 4 April 1941)

"Our courtyard at 41 Sienna Street is the scene of many happenings during the day, perhaps because more well-to-do people live here than anywhere else." (71, 12 June 1941)

"The house across from ours, Number 42, was burned during the siege. This morning a middle-aged woman sat down in front of the ruins. Her bare feet, which she stretched out in front of her, were covered with festering wounds, her face was swollen with scurvy, and her nostrils were unnaturally dilated, as though she were suffocating." (86–87)

"Today we received a communication from the housing office concerning the janitorial job my father is supposed to take over at 10 Chlodna Street. He must go there at once, but we shall be allowed to move in only after the street is walled up." (120, 17 December 1941)

[After relating a surprise re-connection with an old friend who escaped Łódź to get to Warsaw] "'Some friends in Lodz asked me to visit their relatives who live at 10 Chlodna Street, and I was looking for their janitor when I found you.'" (153, 17 May 1942)

"Close to us is the ghetto's 'Capitol.' At 20 Chlodna Street are the residences of President Czerniakow, Colonel Szerynski, the chief of the Jewish police and the high officials of the various Jewish institutions. The photographic firm Baum-Forbert is at the same address, and a large portrait of Czerniakow has been hanging in front of the house for several days." (128, 16 January 1942)

"At 20 Chlodna Street the charge for entering the terrace-like roof is one zloty fifty groszy. There are folding chairs, cool drinks, and a bird's eye view of Warsaw." (148, 7 May 1942)

"The Germans have decided to make a film of life in the ghetto. Early this morning, they set up a powerful camera in front of 20 Chlodna Street and took pictures of the street." (149, 8 May 1942)

"Last week self-supporting popular kitchens began to function in Warsaw. One of these is close to us, at 16 Sienna Street. A meal in such a kitchen consists of potato or cabbage soup and a tiny portion of vegetables. Twice a week one receives a tiny piece of meat which costs one zloty twenty groszy." (32, 12 July 1940)

"The metallurgical and related courses will be given in the community building at 26 Grzybowska Street; the courses in industrial drawing will be given at 16 Sienna Street, not far from my home. . . . Unfortunately "pull" playes a large part in the selection of students. At first I rebelled agains this, but when I realized that my chances of being admitted were slight, I finally decided to resort to the same means." (50, 17 February 1941)

"At 16 Sienna Street, in the house where our courses in graphic arts took place, a new café, directed by Tatiana Epstein, has been opened. . . . Famous artists give performances there, among them the virtuoso Wladislaw Spielman. In a few days this café is going to run a contest for young talent. . . . I have entered my name among the competitors." (55, 9 April 1941)

[After a story of Uncle Abie, Jewish police officer, abetting smugglers and running for his life from the Nazis.] "He managed to enter a passage that led to the uneven side of Chlodna Street; at Number 17 is a Jewish Police station." (148)
"The janitor at 8 Chlodna Street is Engineer Plonskier, formerly our neighbor on Sienna Street. Many doctors live on our street, and there is a doctor's or dentist's sign on almost every door." (128)

[After a description of children smugglers.] "The next morning the little foragers try once more to cross the ghetto boundary at the corner of Sienna and Zelazna Streets; perhaps the same kindly guard will be there who let them pass once before." (73)

"The smart world meets at the Café Sztuka (Art) on Leszno Street, the most popular establishment in the ghetto. At elegantly set tables, to the sound of a brilliant orchestra, the high society of the ghetto disports itself." (60)

"Two of my friends have acquired papers proving that they are nationals of a South American republic. Thanks to these they can circulate freely in the city. They went boldly to the Gestapo headquarters at Bruehl Palace to have these papers sealed with a swastika; and the German experts did not realize that they were forged. They can even go to the country to buy food. With such documents they have at least a 90 per cent chance of survival—the other Jews have only a 10 per cent chance at most." (30)

"Today a new group of uniformed Jewish officials appeared in the ghetto. They belong to the special Commission for the Fight Against Speculators, whose task it is to regulate the prices of various articles. . . . [T]hey are suspected of being tools of the Gestapo. Their organization has been nicknamed "The Thirteen," because its office is at 13 Leszno Street." (43, 25 December 1940)

"The number of professional schools and courses in the ghetto is increasing. The ORT organization has opened a special course for girls under the direction of Roma Brandes . . . The ORT has obtained two halls for these courses: at 13 Leszno Street and 13 Nalewki Street." (54, 4 April 1941)

"When I came home [from a party for young designers] I found a sealed envelope which Tadek Szajer had left for me. . . .¶On the back of the photograph is an inscription which shows how his conscience is plaguing him. 'Some day, years hence, when I am far from you, you will perhaps recall the ambulance service, 13 Leszno Street . . . and Tadek who loves you very, very much.'" (123–24, 28 December 1941)

"The number of professional schools and courses in the ghetto is increasing. The ORT organization has opened a special course for girls under the direction of Roma Brandes . . . The ORT has obtained two halls for these courses: at 13 Leszno Street and 13 Nalewki Street." (54)

"The relief office of the American colony in Warsaw is situated at 14 Mokotowska Street. Once a month all American citizens receive a large package of foodstuffs for the sum of eleven zlotys—but its real value is three hundred, for it often contains articles that are unobtainable elsewhere at any price whatsoever.¶The question of obtaining food is becoming ever more pressing." (40)

"The Jewish police is an accomplished fact. . . . Central Police Headquarters, the so-called KSP, are at 15 Ogrodowa Street; the five regional offices are on Twarda Street, Ogrodowa Street, Leszno Street, at Gesia near Nalewcki, and near the Jewish cemetary." (42)

[One of the rare times Mary Berg may have gotten an address wrong. The Pawiak prison is also given as 24 Dzielna St.] "I have recognized other acquaintances among the workers employed across the street. Edzia Piaskowska's brother oversees a large group of workers at the children's home. Zelig is an overseer in the building adjoining ours, at Number 24 [sic] Dzielna Street." (180)

"Yesterday we were in a state of utter despair. The card with our furniture was ready, and we planned to occupy temporary quarters in the room of my schoolmate, Zosia Zakheim, at 24 Panska Street. Suddenly, Ola Szmuszkiewicz, my friend, came running to tell us that she had found two rooms for us in a large comfortable apartment on Leszno Street, where there is even a piano." (105)

"A search took place a few days ago in Sienna Street, at the corner of Sosnowa. The Nazis allegedly had come to requisition the furniture of a Jewish tenant, and while doing this discovered a radio station." (67, 10 June 1941)

"The window faces that part of Sienna Street which is near Sosnowa and is always a scene of great animation. At the corner of the street there is a newsstand. It goes without saying that the newspapers sold there are smuggled, because officially only the Gazeta Zydowska can be sold in the ghetto." (85, 31 July 1941)

"The metallurgical and related courses will be given in the community building at 26 Grzybowska Street; the courses in industrial drawing will be given at 16 Sienna Street, not far from my home. . . . Unfortunately 'pull' playes a large part in the selection of students. At first I rebelled agains this, but when I realized that my chances of being admitted were slight, I finally decided to resort to the same means." (50)

"[After a lament for Judenrat president Adam Czerniakow]¶President Czerniakow lives at 26 Elektoralna Street. I often come to this house because a friend of mine lives there, but I have never met the president on the stairs or in the street. He seldom goes out, for he is entirely absorbed by his heavy tasks. . . . ¶I have had occasion to see President Czerniakow during his visits to our school." (57)

"Close to our window we sometimes see a Jewish policeman walking out of Numbers 27–31 Dzielna Street, which is Dr. Janusz Korczak's children's home. I can see many little beds through the windows of this house. During moments of quiet I hear the sweet voices of the children who live there, quite unaware of what is happening around them." (168, 20 July 1942)

"On the ground floor of Numbers 27–31 Dzielna Street pharmaceutical items are now being sorted. . . . In one of the ground-floor windows I saw one of my former teachers at the school of graphic design. He often looks up at me and smiles bitterly. What is he thinking? His pupil is behind bars, and he himself works under the Nazi whip." (180)

"The area of the ghetto has been considerably reduced. Its boundary now runs along Smocza, Gesia, Franciszkanska, Bonifraterska, Muranowska, Pokorna, Stawki, Dzika and Szczesliwa Street, and Parysowski Square. All the community institutions and remaining workshops were ordered to transfer to the new area. This order of the German authorities bears the date of September 27." (189)
properties.notes: Berg never delimits the ghetto in its entirety in other entries, but that's probably as much because it was very complex as because she a) didn't care to do it and b) was working her mind differently after being in the Pawiak prison for 2 months.
properties.nameEn: Getto boundaries after the first 1942 Aktion

properties.notes: Not sure how the word 'block' is getting translated from Polish or Yiddish here.
properties.desc:
"The Jewish police now occupies an entire block on Ostrowska and Wolynska Streets. All the Jewish policemen and their families were ordered to leave their former apartments in the various quarters of the ghetto and to occupy the emptied and looted apartments of the deported." (184–85, 20 September 1942)

"Yesterday was the Day of Atonement, and on this sacred day the Nazis, as is their custom, chose to blockade Ostrowska and Wolynska Streets. Out of the 2,500 policemen they singled out 380 for continued service, and more than 2,000 others were deported, together with their families." (186, 22 September 1942)
"Our first performance took place early this month at 5 Przejazd, in the Joint Distribution Committee office. Our success surpassed all expectations, and the receipts were considerable." (36)

"My father stayed in the cellar the entire day and prayed to God while my mother looked for a new apartment. She has not found anything so far, but brought home a new piece of sad news: it seems that the Nazis are going to liquidate the so-called Little Ghetto and add only Chlodna Street and the further end of Zelazna to the Big Ghetto." (103)

"My father stayed in the cellar the entire day and prayed to God while my mother looked for a new apartment. She has not found anything so far, but brought home a new piece of sad news: it seems that the Nazis are going to liquidate the so-called Little Ghetto and add only Chlodna Street and the further end of Zelazna to the Big Ghetto." (103)
properties.notes: Not immediately obvious what her language means specifically, but Chlodna is short and Zelazna is short enough that this stretch must be what she's talking about. Engelking-Boni maps will be helpful here.

properties.desc: "Komitetowa Street, near Grzybowska, is a living graveyard of children devoured by scurvy. The inhabitants of this street live in long cellar-caves into which no ray of the sun ever reaches." (88)

"The Nazis strictly follow the Jewish calendar. Yesterday before sunset, at the time of the Kol Nidre prayers which open the Day of Atonement services, big white placards were posted with the sad announcement that before October 5 the inhabitants of the right [odd-numbered] side of Sienna Street, of sections of Gesia and Muranowska Streets and of a number of houses near the ghetto boundaries must leave their apartments." (103)

"On Sunday, September 6, the Jewish police force received an order to prepare for another campaign. This followed an announcement published by the community in the name of the Resettlement Commission, according to which all the remaining inhabitants of the 'Big Ghetto' (within the limits of Smocza, Gesia, Zamenhof, and Szczesliwa Streets, and Parisowski Square [sic]) were to report on September 5 for registration." (184)
"I feel as though I have been in Vittel for a long time. ¶This is a large camp. In the park there are three hotels: the Grand Hotel, the Vittel Palace, and the Ceres." (219)

properties.notes: Location is American embassy in Warsaw, not consulate in Lodz, and it's not for sure that this is the location of the embassy. The Warsaw phone directory of 1939 says "Ujazdowska 29", so is that a misprint for Ujazdowskie?
properties.desc: [The indicated location is the American Embassy in Warsaw, the destination of Mary Berg's mother.]"Last week we received a letter from the American consulate, summoning my mother to Warsaw. The mailman who brought us this letter could not refrain from expressing his envy over the fact that we have American connections." (24)

"Every day, morning and afternoon, when I go to school, I am not sure whether I will return alive. I have to go past two of the most dangerous German sentry posts: at the corner of Zelazna and Chlodna Streets near the bridge, and at the corner of Krochmalna and Grzybowska Streets." (135)

"Every day, morning and afternoon, when I go to school, I am not sure whether I will return alive. I have to go past two of the most dangerous German sentry posts: at the corner of Zelazna and Chlodna Streets near the bridge, and at the corner of Krochmalna and Grzybowska Streets." (135)

[Berg's mother has to go to Gestapo HQ, helped by 'Z'.] "[Z.] was arrested while trying to cross the German border with a forged passport, and after long and refined tortures was compelled to work for the Gestapo. He is now employed as a Polish-German interpreter at the Gestapo headquarters on Aleja Szucha. He comes from a well-known Lodz family, and it seems that despite his position he has remained a decent man." (155)
